block.p: It may be a rough summer for vacationers in their campers and sport utility vehicles. Oil prices shot up to more than $32 a barrel, amid growing fear that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might decide not to lift production when ministers meet this week in Vienna. OPEC has already discarded an informal agreement to automatically raise production by 500,000 barrels a day if the 20-day average price climbed above $28. American motorists are already paying the highest gasoline prices in a decade; in the Midwest, some gas is selling for more than $2 a gallon.
